docs.snippet: ABOUT halfway through the one-woman show in Spanish by the Argentine actress Norma Aleandro, I removed the headset that was available for simultaneous English translation. Language almost did not matter. Miss Aleandro's eyes and hands and balletic...
docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT halfway through the one-woman show in Spanish by the Argentine actress Norma Aleandro, I removed the headset that was available for simultaneous English translation. Language almost did not matter. Miss Aleandro's eyes and hands and balletic movements succeeded, like a pantominist's, in conveying the meaning of her small, personalized stories.

docs.snippet: Pedro Monge, a native of Cuba, citizen of the United States and resident of Queens, remembers the party of Cubans and Ecuadoreans at which someone made an innocent remark about Cuban black beans. Soon, he recalls, the casual aside turned into a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pedro Monge, a native of Cuba, citizen of the United States and resident of Queens, remembers the party of Cubans and Ecuadoreans at which someone made an innocent remark about Cuban black beans. Soon, he recalls, the casual aside turned into a debate over whether Cuban or Ecuadorean cuisine was tastier. Underlying the debate over beans, he said, was something more serious. ''In one way or another we all want to demonstrate that our nationality is better than the other,'' Mr. Monge said.

headline.main: LIFE IN HISPANIC QUEENS: TOGETHER, YET SEPARATE

docs.snippet: JORGE, A 31-YEAR-OLD COMPUTER programmer in Toronto, has recurring nightmares about the kidnappers in Guatemala City who took him away one summer morning. They wore civilian clothes but they carried guns and were almost certainly soldiers. They took...
docs.lead_paragraph: JORGE, A 31-YEAR-OLD COMPUTER programmer in Toronto, has recurring nightmares about the kidnappers in Guatemala City who took him away one summer morning. They wore civilian clothes but they carried guns and were almost certainly soldiers. They took Jorge, a former student activist, to a makeshift jail where they tortured him for 24 hours straight. Jorge's wrists and ankles still bear deep scars from the manacles that locked his hands and legs behind his back while electric shocks were applied to all parts of his body. It is his only proof of a seven-week secret incarceration many North Americans find difficult to comprehend. ''For Canadians, a prisoner is someone who did something wrong,'' says Jorge, who asked that his last name not be used because he fears for the safety of relatives in Guatemala. But last year, he said, a 2-year-old boy with his fingernails pulled out was found among some corpses. ''What could a 2-year-old boy do to be killed?'' Jorge asks.

byline.original: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN; Christopher S. Wren is head of The New York Times's Ottawa bureau

docs.snippet: The Soviet Union announced economic initiatives today that signaled a new willingness to become actively involved in the commerce and politics of Western business.   Moscow said it was cutting oil exports to the West by 100,000 barrels a day, or...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union announced economic initiatives today that signaled a new willingness to become actively involved in the commerce and politics of Western business. Moscow said it was cutting oil exports to the West by 100,000 barrels a day, or about 6 percent, at the request of Iran, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Western diplomats said it was a significant gesture of support for OPEC's efforts to stabilize oil prices. Moscow also said it had petitioned the Secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to give the Soviet Union observer status at the next round of multilateral trade negotiations, scheduled to open Sept. 15 in Punta del Este, Uruguay.

Ivanov, a Foreign Ministry economic spokesman, said the Soviet Union was pressing to send official observers to next month's meeting in Uruguay of the 90-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

docs.snippet: AMERICA'S dwindling farm population now accounts for only 2.2 percent of the nation, fewer than 6,000,000 people. But the Federal Government's efforts to help those still on the farm have strained relations with some of Washington's closest allies.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICA'S dwindling farm population now accounts for only 2.2 percent of the nation, fewer than 6,000,000 people. But the Federal Government's efforts to help those still on the farm have strained relations with some of Washington's closest allies. To curb the giant trade deficit and meet farmers' concerns in an election year, the United States, the world's leading food producer, is subsidizing exports of wheat, sugar, rice and other commodities. State Department officials say these sales have been managed so as to minimize their impact on world markets. But they have piled new pressures on depressed prices, affecting the economies of Australia, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, Argentina, the Caribbean Basin countries and the European Community.

docs.snippet: The major nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are not expected to let the Soviet Union join in a new round of global trade talks, international trade experts said today.   But instead of outright rejection of Moscow's request to...
docs.lead_paragraph: The major nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are not expected to let the Soviet Union join in a new round of global trade talks, international trade experts said today. But instead of outright rejection of Moscow's request to participate, made earlier this month in Geneva, the trade ministers of GATT's member nations are likely to seek further information from the Soviets about their trade intentions. ''All the signals at this point are negative,'' said one Reagan Administration trade official, commenting on chances that the ministers would accede to the Soviet request at their meeting beginning Sept. 15 at Punta del Este, Uruguay. An official of the European Community said: ''This is the start of a process. I expect the ministers next month will say they can't decide and seek more data.''
